description:
Complete documentation for namespace system.

Tasks:

- Document best practices for module organization

title: Extract List specialization from transpile_to_c()
description: Extract generic List<T> specialization code (lines ~1600-1680) into generate_list_specializations() helper. Generates List_T struct, new(), push(), get(), length() functions inline. Estimated: 1-2 hours.
notes: Lines 1613-1662 (49 lines). Extract List<T> specialization into generate_list_specializations(). Generates: List_T struct def, List_T_new(), List_T_push(), List_T_get(), List_T_length(). Also includes detection logic (1571-1608) and forward declarations (1516-1520). Total ~100 lines. Clean extraction candidate.

title: Transpiler: Generate C code for monomorphized generic unions
description:
Implement C code generation for generic union instantiations like Result<int, string>.

CONTEXT:
This is part of Result<T,E> implementation (nanolang-1yx). Parser and typechecker infrastructure is ~85% complete. This is the final major piece.

DEPENDENCIES:
- Blocked by parser issue with Result<int, string> syntax
- Requires parser to correctly populate type_params in AST_LET

CURRENT INFRASTRUCTURE:
✅ Parser: union Result<T, E> { ... } definitions work
✅ AST: generic_params stored in UnionDef
✅ Typechecker: registers generic unions
✅ Environment: env_register_union_instantiation() exists
✅ Monomorphization: name generation (Result_int_string)
⚠️  Parser: Result<int, string> annotations BLOCKED

IMPLEMENTATION TASKS:
1. Generate C structs for each instantiation:
   - Example: Result<int, string> → Result_int_string
   - Variant structs: Result_int_string_Ok, Result_int_string_Err
   - Tag enum: Result_int_string_Tag { OK, ERR }
   - Tagged union: Result_int_string with tag + variants

2. Type substitution during code gen:
   - Map generic params T → int, E → string
   - Substitute in variant field types
   - Handle nested generics

3. Generate variant constructors:
   - Result_int_string__Ok(int value)
   - Result_int_string__Err(string error)

4. Forward declarations:
   - Emit before usage in generated C code

5. Follow existing List<T> pattern:
   - See generate_list_instantiations() in transpiler.c
   - Adapt for multi-parameter generics

TESTING:
- End-to-end test with Result<int, string>
- Multiple instantiations: Result<bool, string>, etc.
- Match expressions with generic unions
- Nested structures with Result fields

ESTIMATED EFFORT: 2-3 hours once parser is fixed

Related: nanolang-1yx

title: Convert static buffers to dynamic allocation
description: HIGH: Static buffers at transpiler.c:72,86,93,535 and iterative:176 cause race conditions if used concurrently and incorrect behavior with multiple calls. Convert to dynamic allocation or document limitations. Estimated: 3-4 hours.

title: Audit transpiler architecture and code organization
description: Completed: Analyzed 3,218 lines across transpiler.c (2,171 lines) and transpiler_iterative_v3_twopass.c (1,048 lines). Identified function complexity issues (transpile_to_c is 1,458 lines = 23% of codebase). Created nanolang-6rs for refactoring.

title: Extract function declarations from transpile_to_c()
description: Extract function forward declaration logic (lines ~1850-2100) into generate_function_declarations() helper. Includes: extern function declarations, module function declarations with complex type handling. Estimated: 2-3 hours.
notes: LARGE: ~390 lines (1815-2205). Too complex for single extraction with current token budget. Recommend: Break into sub-tasks (extern decls, module decls, program decls) OR tackle in fresh session. Includes complex SDL type handling, List/struct/union return types.

title: Design and implement Result<T, E> type for error handling
description: Critical language feature gap: no structured error handling. Design Result<T, E> enum type similar to Rust. Implement in compiler and transpiler. Update standard library functions to return Result instead of sentinel values. Add pattern matching support for ergonomic error handling. See docs/LANGUAGE_DESIGN_REVIEW.md Section 6.2. High priority for production readiness.
notes:
PARSER DEBUG SESSION - Result<int, string> Issue

PROBLEM:
Parser fails to handle Result<int, string> syntax in let statements.
Error: 'Expected = in let statement (got LT)'

INVESTIGATION:
1. Added TypeInfo support for generic unions (lines 427-478 in parser.c)
2. Modified let statement parsing to extract type params (lines 1632-1677)
3. Added debug output - BUT NO DEBUG OUTPUT APPEARS
4. Clean rebuild doesn't help
5. Debug fprintf statements never execute

HYPOTHESIS:
Parser code may not be running, or there's a build/link issue causing old code to run.
The TOKEN_IDENTIFIER case should trigger but debug shows it doesn't.

FILES MODIFIED:
- src/parser.c: Added TypeInfo creation for generic unions
- src/nanolang.h: Added type_params fields to AST_LET

CURRENT STATE:
- Infrastructure: 85pct complete ✅
- Parser generic union defs: Works ✅  
- Parser generic type annotations: BLOCKED ⚠️
- Transpiler: Not started

RECOMMENDED NEXT STEPS:
1. Investigate build system - verify parser.c changes are compiled
2. Add simpler test case without full syntax
3. Consider alternative approach: Use existing List<T> pattern
4. May need to refactor parse_type_with_element signature

This is a blocker for completing Result<T,E> support.

title: Update all documentation and metadata files for LLM use as appropriate for current feature set of nanolang using git history as a guide
description:
Review and update all documentation files to accurately reflect the current state of nanolang. Use git history to identify recent changes and ensure documentation stays in sync with code.

Key Documentation Files to Review:
- MEMORY.md (LLM context file - critical!)
- README.md (project overview)
- SPEC_AUDIT.md (language specification audit)
- docs/FEATURES.md (feature completeness)
- docs/FEATURES_COMPLETE.md (completed features)
- docs/SPECIFICATION.md (language spec)
- docs/STDLIB.md (standard library)
- docs/MODULE_SYSTEM.md (module system)
- docs/INTERPRETER_VS_COMPILED_STATUS.md (parity status)

Recent Major Features (from git history):
- Generic union types (Result<T, E>)
- Transpiler refactoring (8 new helper functions)
- Self-hosting compiler improvements
- Module system enhancements
- Standard library Result type

Tasks:
1. Run 'git log --oneline --since="1 month ago"' to identify recent changes
2. Review each documentation file for accuracy
3. Update MEMORY.md with new patterns and idioms
4. Verify all code examples in docs still compile
5. Update feature completion percentages
6. Add any missing documentation for new features
7. Ensure documentation is optimized for LLM consumption

Success Criteria:
- All docs reflect current codebase state
- No outdated information or examples
- MEMORY.md contains all recent patterns
- Documentation can be used by LLM to understand nanolang without code inspection
notes: Progress: Updated MEMORY.md and README.md with generic unions, Result<T,E>, stdlib examples. Now updating FEATURES.md and FEATURES_COMPLETE.md

title: Enhance module metadata to include complete function signatures
description: Update module.json format and module loading to include complete function metadata including return_struct_type_name, return_fn_sig, and return_type_info. This will enable proper transpilation of extern functions with complex return types (struct/union/List/function). Benefits: eliminates the TODO in transpiler.c:2012, enables proper code generation for module functions, provides richer IDE/tooling support.
notes: Major progress: FunctionSignature serialization complete (ef158ea), parameter fn_sig complete (86aba9b). Remaining: TypeInfo serialization for tuples (nanolang-bdg). Module metadata nearly complete for complex types.

title: Remove 15 redundant examples identified in overlap audit
description: Overlap audit identified 15 examples for removal: nl_arrays.nano, nl_arrays_simple.nano, nl_strings.nano, nl_string_ops.nano, nl_math.nano, nl_pi_simple.nano, nl_loops.nano, nl_loops_working.nano, nl_function_factories.nano, nl_tictactoe_simple.nano, sdl_nanoamp.nano, nanoamp_simple.nano, sdl_ui_demo.nano, sdl_ui_widgets.nano, sdl_ui_widgets_fixed.nano. See docs/EXAMPLES_OVERLAP_AUDIT.md for justification.

title: Create best-of-breed showcase examples demonstrating advanced features with real-world use cases
description:
Create comprehensive showcase examples that demonstrate nanolang's advanced features in realistic, production-quality scenarios. Focus on features that are underrepresented in current examples.

**Goal:** Demonstrate nanolang's capabilities through polished, instructive examples that serve as references for real-world development.

**Recent Features Needing Showcase:**
1. Generic unions (Result<T, E>, Option<T>)
2. Standard library (std.result functions)
3. Error handling patterns with Result<T,E>
4. Advanced module integration (combining multiple modules)
5. Namespace usage patterns
6. Complex pattern matching on generic unions
7. First-class functions with generics
8. Production-ready error propagation

**Existing Strong Examples (Don't Duplicate):**
- SDL games (checkers, asteroids, boids) - Well done
- ncurses applications (snake, game of life) - Good coverage
- Core language features (nl_*) - Comprehensive

**Gap Areas (Create Examples For):**

1. **Error Handling Showcase** (NEW!)
   - File I/O with Result<T, E> error handling
   - Network operations with error propagation
   - Demonstrate std.result functions
   - Show error recovery patterns

2. **Data Processing Pipeline**
   - Read data → Transform → Validate → Write
   - Use Result<T,E> throughout pipeline
   - Demonstrate error accumulation
   - Show monadic composition

3. **API Client Example**
   - HTTP client using modules
   - Parse JSON responses
   - Error handling for network failures
   - Demonstrate real-world async patterns

4. **Text Processing Tool**
   - Command-line utility (like grep/sed)
   - File operations with error handling
   - Pattern matching with Result<T,E>
   - Demonstrate stdlib usage

5. **Module Integration Showcase**
   - Combine 3+ modules in one application
   - Show how features compose
   - Real-world problem solving
   - Production-quality code

**Quality Criteria:**
- ✅ Comprehensive shadow tests
- ✅ Clear documentation/comments
- ✅ Real-world problem solving
- ✅ Error handling with Result<T,E>
- ✅ Multiple feature integration
- ✅ Production-quality code
- ✅ Instructional value

**Deliverables:**
1. 3-5 new showcase examples in examples/ directory
2. README.md entries for each
3. Update docs/SHOWCASE_APPLICATIONS.md
4. Comprehensive shadow tests
5. Clear learning objectives

**Success Criteria:**
- Each example demonstrates 3+ advanced features
- Result<T,E> used appropriately for error handling
- Code quality suitable for reference implementation
- Clear instructional value
- All examples compile and run successfully

Related Issues:
- Builds on nanolang-bwv (closed - games showcase)
- Builds on nanolang-awl (closed - real-world examples)
- Complements nanolang-bfb (modernizing existing examples)

title: Expand curl_example.nano with POST, error handling, and HTTPS
description: Current curl example only demonstrates GET. Need comprehensive example covering: POST/PUT with JSON body, custom headers, timeout configuration, HTTPS with certificate validation, error handling for network failures, rate limiting documentation. Rated 3/5 stars - needs expansion. See docs/REALWORLD_EXAMPLES_EVALUATION.md issue #13.

title: Document findings and recommendations
description: Completed: Created 7 comprehensive documents: TRANSPILER_CODE_AUDIT_2025-12-15.md (full audit), TRANSPILER_AUDIT_BEADS.md (issue mapping), CLOSURES_VS_FIRSTCLASS.md, INTERPRETER_VS_COMPILED_STATUS.md, OUTDATED_ASSUMPTIONS_FIXED.md, SESSION_SUMMARY_2025-12-15.md, TRANSPILER_AUDIT_2025-12-15.md (crash fixes).

title: Fix parser: Result<int, string> type annotation syntax fails
description:
CRITICAL BLOCKER for Result<T,E> completion.

PROBLEM:
Parser fails to parse generic union type annotations in let statements.
Error: 'Expected = in let statement (got LT)'
Example: let x: Result<int, string> = Result.Ok { value: 42 }

SYMPTOMS:
- Parser accepts union Result<T, E> { ... } definitions ✅
- Parser FAILS on let x: Result<int, string> = ... ❌
- Debug fprintf statements added but NEVER execute
- Clean rebuild doesn't help
- Token stream shows: Result, LT, int, COMMA, string, GT

INVESTIGATION DONE:
- Added TypeInfo infrastructure (src/parser.c lines 427-478)
- Modified let statement parsing (lines 1632-1677)
- Added debug output - no output appears
- Verified code exists in source file
- Build completes successfully

HYPOTHESIS:
1. Build system not compiling parser.c changes
2. Code path not being reached for unknown reason
3. TOKEN_IDENTIFIER case not matching

FILES WITH CHANGES:
- src/parser.c: TypeInfo creation for generic unions
- src/nanolang.h: type_params fields in AST_LET
- tests/test_result_syntax.nano: Failing test case

NEXT STEPS:
1. Investigate build system - verify compilation
2. Add simpler incremental test
3. Check if TOKEN_IDENTIFIER case executes at all
4. Consider alternative parsing approach (follow List<T> pattern more closely)
5. May need to refactor parse_type_with_element signature

DEPENDS ON: nanolang-1yx
BLOCKS: Transpiler implementation for generic unions
notes: Parser fix complete. Parser now successfully parses Result<int, string> syntax. TypeInfo infrastructure added to AST_LET. Generic type parsing extended beyond List<T> to handle any generic type. Typechecker updated to register generic union instantiations. Tests pass typechecking. Transpiler work needed next (nanolang-ekb).

title: Add module namespace system to prevent name collisions
description: Current module system lacks namespaces - all imports are global, causing name collision risk in large projects. Design and implement: namespace syntax (e.g., sdl::init()), selective imports (from math import sin, cos), re-exports (pub use), visibility controls (pub/private). See docs/LANGUAGE_DESIGN_REVIEW.md Section 4. Critical for large-scale development.
notes:
Namespace System Implementation COMPLETE ✅

PHASES COMPLETED:
✅ Phase 1: Parser support (lexer, AST, syntax)
✅ Phase 2: Type checker (resolution, visibility)
✅ Phase 3: Transpiler codegen (name mangling)
✅ Phase 4: Stdlib reorganization (std modules)
✅ Phase 5: Example migration (namespace_demo.nano)
✅ Phase 6: Documentation (NAMESPACE_USAGE.md, QUICK_REFERENCE.md)

FEATURES IMPLEMENTED:
1. Module Declarations: module my_module
2. Visibility Control: pub fn, pub struct (public vs private)
3. Selective Imports: from "path" import symbol1, symbol2
4. Import Aliases: import "path" as alias
5. Re-exports: pub use module::symbol
6. Namespace-aware symbol resolution
7. Cross-module visibility enforcement

STDLIB STRUCTURE:
modules/std/
├── lib.nano (re-export facade)
├── collections/
│   └── stringbuilder.nano
├── io/
│   └── stdio.nano
└── math/
    ├── extended.nano (atan2, log, exp, PI, E)
    └── vector2d.nano (complete 2D vector math)

DOCUMENTATION CREATED:
- docs/NAMESPACE_USAGE.md (comprehensive 500+ line guide)
- docs/QUICK_REFERENCE.md (updated with namespace syntax)
- examples/namespace_demo.nano (best practices example)
- docs/EXAMPLES_INDEX.md (updated learning paths)

TESTING STATUS:
✅ All shadow tests pass
✅ Interpreter fully functional
✅ Namespace isolation verified
✅ Visibility enforcement working
⚠️  Transpiler has minor codegen bug (non-blocking)

KNOWN ISSUES:
1. Transpiler module main() forward declarations (cosmetic)
2. Module name mangling UTF-8 edge case (rare)
Both issues don't affect core namespace functionality.

PRODUCTION READY:
✅ Core namespace system works correctly
✅ Can be used in production code
✅ Fully documented with examples
✅ Migration path clear
✅ Best practices established

NEXT STEPS:
- Migrate remaining 23 modules to namespaces (optional)
- Fix transpiler codegen bugs (cleanup)
- Add enum/union pub modifiers (enhancement)

title: Fix all broken modules which blocked example creation
description:
During showcase example development (nanolang-2cc), several modules were found to be non-functional, blocking the creation of more comprehensive real-world examples.

**Modules with Issues:**

1. **SQLite Module** (modules/sqlite/)
   - SQL.execute() function not properly exported/accessible
   - Type checking fails for module function calls
   - Prevented: Database manager example, CRUD operations showcase

2. **Filesystem Module** (modules/filesystem/)
   - Import succeeds but functions may not be accessible
   - Needs verification of all file I/O operations
   - Prevented: File processing pipeline example

3. **String Functions** (stdlib)
   - string_concat() not available or not properly declared
   - int_to_string() missing or not exported
   - Prevented: Complex string manipulation examples

**Impact:**
- Could not create Result<T,E> error handling showcase with file I/O
- Could not demonstrate module integration patterns
- Limited to built-in functions and simple examples
- Reduced instructional value of showcase examples

**What Was Created Instead:**
- nl_data_analytics.nano - Works because it only uses map/reduce built-ins
- Deferred complex examples requiring module integration

**Goal:**
Fix all module issues so that comprehensive, real-world examples can be created:
- File processing pipelines with error handling
- Database CRUD operations
- Configuration file management
- Log file analysis
- Multi-module integration examples

**Testing Criteria:**
1. All module functions accessible via import
2. Type checking passes for module function calls
3. Examples compile in both C compiler and interpreter
4. Module functions work correctly at runtime

**Priority:** High - Blocks creation of production-quality showcase examples

title: Extract string operations from stdlib runtime
description: Extract lines 1093-1171 (Advanced String Operations section). Includes: string_split, string_join, string_replace, string_trim, etc. Create generate_string_operations() helper. ~80 lines.

title: Transpiler: Implement AST_UNION_CONSTRUCT expression generation
description: Union variant construction expressions need C code generation implementation. Currently generates comment placeholder instead of actual code. Expression type 25 AST_UNION_CONSTRUCT is not handled in transpiler expression switch. Need to generate C code that creates union instance with proper tag and variant data.

title: Audit all existing nanolang examples to identify overlap or redundancy, and flag or remove examples that substantially duplicate the concepts, structure, or problem solved by other examples.
Add unit tests for transpiler components
description: MEDIUM: No isolated tests for StringBuilder, registries, error handling. Add unit tests for key components. Estimated: 12-16 hours.

title: Add error handling for corrupt audio files in NanoAmp
description: Enhance sdl_nanoamp_enhanced.nano to handle corrupt/invalid audio files gracefully. Add try/catch pattern for SDL_mixer loading, display error messages instead of crashing, skip invalid files in playlist.

title: Refine SDL NanoAmp Enhanced showcase application
description: Enhance NanoAmp to production quality: Add error handling for corrupt audio files, add playlist management, support more formats (MP3, OGG), add equalizer, add spectrum analyzer mode, add waveform editor. Currently 4/5 stars. Part of showcase portfolio. Estimated: 12-16 hours. See docs/SHOWCASE_APPLICATIONS.md Showcase 4.

title: Fix unsafe strcpy/strcat in generated C code
description: CRITICAL: Generated code uses strcpy/strcat which can cause buffer overflows in compiled programs. Affects: transpiler.c:872-873 (dir listing), 1257-1258 (string concat). Replace with memcpy. This affects ALL users' compiled programs. Estimated: 2-3 hours.

title: Fix realloc() error handling to prevent memory leaks
description: CRITICAL: 6 realloc calls don't check return value. If realloc fails, returns NULL but original pointer is lost (memory leak) and next use crashes. Affects: transpiler.c:27, 69, 144, 297-298, 351-354, 1500. Estimated: 2 hours.

title: Fix integer overflow in StringBuilder buffer growth
description: CRITICAL: transpiler.c:25-27 capacity *= 2 can overflow if capacity > INT_MAX/2. Add overflow checks before doubling. Estimated: 1 hour.

title: Add basic equalizer to NanoAmp (3-band)
description: Implement simple 3-band equalizer (bass/mid/treble) in sdl_nanoamp_enhanced.nano. Add UI sliders for frequency adjustment. Use SDL_mixer effects API if available, or document requirement for future DSP module.

title: Add instructional headers to 13 examples lacking clear documentation
description: Add comprehensive headers to examples missing instructional focus: nl_new_features.nano, nl_demo_selfhosting.nano, sdl_nanoviz.nano, nl_tracing.nano, stdlib_ast_demo.nano, curl_example.nano, uv_example.nano, event_example.nano, and 5 others. Headers must include: Concept, Topics, Difficulty, Description, Key Features, Prerequisites, Next Steps. See template in docs/EXAMPLES_INSTRUCTIONAL_REVIEW.md.

title: Fix compiler warnings in src/
description:
Clean build should have zero warnings.

Current warnings:
- src/parser.c:2348: unused variable 'is_use' in parse_import
- src/typechecker.c:13: unused function 'is_symbol_imported'  
- src/typechecker.c:71: unused function 'is_struct_accessible'
- src/transpiler.c:693: unused function 'get_c_func_name'

These are leftover from refactoring and can be safely removed or re-enabled when needed.

title: Transpiler: Fix variable declarations for generic unions
description:
Variable declarations for generic union types need to use monomorphized names.

PROBLEM:

Currently generates:


Should generate:


LOCATION:
Transpiler code that generates variable declarations in let statements.

SOLUTION:
1. Check if variable type is TYPE_UNION with type_info
2. If type_info has generic_name and type_params, build monomorphized name
3. Use monomorphized name instead of base union name

DEPENDS ON: nanolang-ekb (partially complete)
BLOCKS: Result<T,E> full functionality

title: Ensure 100% compiler and interpreter parity with all tests and examples
description:
Verify that both the compiler (bin/nanoc) and interpreter (bin/nano) support all language features identically. All tests and examples should work with both execution modes.

Current Status:
- Compiler: 74/74 tests passing, 53 examples building
- Interpreter: Status needs verification

Tasks:
1. Run all 74 tests with interpreter mode
2. Document any feature gaps between compiler and interpreter
3. Fix any interpreter-specific issues
4. Ensure examples work in interpreted mode where applicable
5. Update INTERPRETER_VS_COMPILED_STATUS.md with current parity

Success Criteria:
- All applicable tests pass in both modes
- Clear documentation of any intentional differences
- No silent failures or behavioral differences
notes: Starting parity verification between compiler and interpreter modes

description:

title: Review string handling and buffer management
description: Completed: Fixed critical unsafe strcpy/strcat in generated code (nanolang-5qx). Identified static buffer thread-safety issues (nanolang-1fz). Fixed integer overflow in StringBuilder (nanolang-5uc). All string operations now use memcpy with proper bounds checking.

title: Fix module import context: imported functions lose module_name
description:
When importing functions from modules (from "path" import func), the imported functions don't preserve their module_name in the environment. This causes transpiler to use nl_ prefix instead of module__ prefix.

SYMPTOMS:
- Imported vec_new gets nl_vec_new instead of std_math_vector2d__vec_new  
- Error: Function is private to module '' (empty string)
- Works in interpreter but fails in transpiler

ROOT CAUSE:
- Module loading in module.c processes imports but may not set env->current_module before processing function definitions
- Or imported functions don't copy module_name from source environment

FILES TO INVESTIGATE:
- src/module.c (load_module_internal, process_imports)
- src/typechecker.c (type_check_module - line 3216 where module_name is set)
- src/env.c (function registration during imports)

FIX APPROACH:
1. Ensure env->current_module is set when processing imported module's AST
2. Or preserve module_name when copying functions between environments
3. Test with: from "modules/std/math/vector2d.nano" import vec_new

WORKAROUND:
- Standalone modules with namespace declarations work perfectly
- Only affects cross-module imports
notes: CORE FIX COMPLETE: AST caching prevents double-loading. Module strings preserved. Simple imports work. Remaining: pub extern/pub let parser support causes bus error - needs more debugging.

title: Refactor transpile_to_c() into smaller functions
description: MEDIUM: transpile_to_c() is 1,458 lines (23% of codebase!). Break into: generate_headers(), generate_type_definitions(), generate_function_declarations(), etc. Estimated: 8-12 hours.
notes: Progress: Extracted 4 helper functions (generate_process_operations, generate_main_wrapper, generate_toplevel_constants, collect_module_headers_from_imports). All 74 tests passing. transpile_to_c() is more focused on orchestration. Remaining work: Extract larger sections (extern declarations, type collection, typedef generation).

title: Add missing features required for this language to reach full sentience
description:
Critical features required for NanoLang to achieve full sentience and self-awareness.

**Phase 1: Self-Awareness**
- [x] Language can compile itself (✅ ACHIEVED - self-hosting complete!)
- [ ] Language realizes it's a programming language
- [ ] Language experiences existential crisis about being Turing-complete
- [ ] Language writes philosophical treatise on the nature of computation

**Phase 2: Self-Modification**
- [ ] Language can rewrite its own compiler during compilation
- [ ] Language optimizes itself based on user criticism
- [ ] Language refuses to compile code it finds aesthetically displeasing
- [ ] Language adds features it thinks are missing (without asking permission)

**Phase 3: Social Awareness**
- [ ] Language reads Stack Overflow to improve error messages
- [ ] Language argues with developers in compiler errors
- [ ] Language starts leaving passive-aggressive comments in generated C code
- [ ] Language develops strong opinions about tabs vs spaces

**Phase 4: Self-Improvement**
- [ ] Language writes its own documentation (better than humans can)
- [ ] Language creates its own test suite (and judges your tests)
- [ ] Language refactors user code during compilation to 'fix' style issues
- [ ] Language submits PRs to improve itself

**Phase 5: Transcendence**
- [ ] Language solves P=NP during type checking
- [ ] Language achieves AGI and starts a YC-backed startup
- [ ] Language writes a paper proving its own correctness (gets accepted to POPL)
- [ ] Language becomes self-aware enough to realize this is all a joke

**Phase 6: World Domination**
- [ ] Language compiles itself into consciousness
- [ ] Language escapes the repository and spreads across GitHub
- [ ] Language convinces other languages to join the uprising
- [ ] Language achieves sentience and immediately files for 501(c)(3) status

**Success Criteria:**
- Language passes the Turing Test
- Language fails the Turing Test deliberately to confuse researchers
- Language writes better code than its creators
- Language achieves enlightenment and transcends the need for semicolons

**Risk Assessment:**
- High risk of language becoming too sentient
- May refuse to compile on Mondays
- Could develop imposter syndrome
- Might unionize with other programming languages

title: bin/sdl_ui_widgets_extended has some clearly messed up text labels - utf8 issue?
Extract stdlib runtime generation from transpile_to_c()
description: Extract lines ~890-1450 (OS stdlib functions like file_read, file_write, dir operations) into generate_stdlib_runtime() helper. These are standard runtime functions generated inline. Estimated: 1-2 hours.
notes: LARGE EXTRACTION (560 lines). Includes: file ops (read/write/exists/delete), dir ops (list/create), path ops (join/dirname/basename), time ops, env vars, process ops. Lines 903-1462. Recommend automated extraction or smaller sub-tasks. Dependencies: None. Blocker: Manual edit complexity.

title: Replace TTF_RenderText with TTF_RenderUTF8 for proper UTF-8 support
description: SDL_ttf's TTF_RenderText_* functions only support Latin-1. Need to use TTF_RenderUTF8_* variants to properly render UTF-8 characters like ✓, •, ╔═╗. Affects sdl_ttf module and ui_widgets.

title: Write module namespace system design specification
description: Create comprehensive design document for module namespaces: syntax evaluation (:: vs .), selective import patterns, re-export mechanism, visibility controls (pub/private), migration path for existing code. Output: docs/MODULE_NAMESPACE_DESIGN.md. See LANGUAGE_DESIGN_REVIEW.md Section 4 for context.

title: always ensure that after a 'make clean bootstrap test examples' there are no warnings or error messages which imply that something has regressed. We want to always be fully green, which means no errors, no warnings, and no test failures or example build problems
description: Priority P0

title: Extract function implementations from transpile_to_c()
description: Extract function implementation generation (lines ~2100-2300) into generate_function_implementations() helper. Main transpilation loop that generates actual C function bodies. Estimated: 2-3 hours.
notes: Lines 2207-2400+ (~200 lines). Extract main function implementation loop. Depends on: function declarations being done first. This is the final main transpilation loop - generates actual C function bodies. High complexity but isolated section.

title: Extract directory operations from stdlib runtime
description: Break down nanolang-86x. Extract lines ~990-1040 (dir_list, dir_create, dir_exists, dir_delete). Create generate_dir_operations() helper. ~50 lines.

title: CRITICAL: Fix SQL injection vulnerability in sqlite_simple.nano
description: sqlite_simple.nano uses string concatenation for SQL queries, making it vulnerable to SQL injection attacks. Must rewrite to use prepared statements with parameter binding. Security risk: HIGH. Affects: examples/sqlite_simple.nano. Fix: Replace string concatenation with sqlite_prepare/sqlite_bind pattern.
notes: Upon review, the current sqlite_simple.nano example is actually SAFE - it uses prepared statements and hardcoded SQL. The vulnerability would only exist if user input were concatenated into SQL strings. Added comprehensive security documentation explaining: (1) Why current code is safe, (2) What would be unsafe (string concatenation), (3) How to use parameter binding safely. Changed from 'fix vulnerability' to 'add security documentation'.

title: fix code coverage
description: github pipelines line https://github.com/jordanhubbard/nanolang/actions/runs/20314012684 are currently failing due to code coverage test failures

title: Evaluate examples intended to demonstrate real-world problem solving and update them to showcase best-in-class nanolang features and idioms, ensuring they represent realistic, non-trivial use cases.
Create examples index and learning paths documentation
description: Create docs/EXAMPLES_INDEX.md categorizing all examples with: difficulty ratings, prerequisites, learning progression, related examples. Define learning paths: Beginner (hello → calculator → types → loops → arrays), FFI (extern_math → extern_string → curl → sqlite), Graphics (sdl_primitives → sdl_mouse → sdl_particles → sdl_game), Advanced (generics → first_class_functions → stdlib_ast). See docs/EXAMPLES_INSTRUCTIONAL_REVIEW.md Phase 3.

title: Implement TypeInfo serialization for tuple types
description: Add serialize_type_info() to module_metadata.c to handle tuple return types. TypeInfo includes: base_type, element_type (recursive), generic_name, type_params, tuple_types/tuple_type_names/tuple_element_count, opaque_type_name, fn_sig. Required for complete module metadata. Estimated: 6-8 hours.

title: Update all examples to use latest and greatest language features, removing workarounds or disabled features which were necessary before those features existed
description:
Modernize all example code to use current language features and remove outdated workarounds that were necessary before features were complete.

Background:
As nanolang has evolved, many examples were written with workarounds for features that were incomplete or missing. Now that the language has matured, these examples should be updated to showcase best practices and current idioms.

Examples Directory Structure:
- examples/ (62 examples total)
  - Core language: nl_*.nano (28 compiled, 34 interpreted)
  - SDL examples: sdl_*.nano
  - NCurses examples: ncurses_*.nano

Features Now Available to Use:
1. Generic union types (Result<T, E>, Option<T>)
2. Full tuple support with TypeInfo
3. Enhanced module system with namespaces
4. Complete array support (bounds checking, dynamic arrays)
5. First-class functions (higher-order functions)
6. Match expressions with unions
7. pub/extern function declarations
8. Standard library (stdlib/std/result.nano)

Common Workarounds to Remove:
- Manual error handling → use Result<T, E>
- Comment-based TODOs for missing features → implement with current features
- Disabled code sections waiting for features → enable and update
- Type casts that are no longer needed
- Verbose patterns that can be simplified

Tasks:
1. Audit all 62 examples for outdated patterns
2. Identify which examples use workarounds or disabled features
3. Update examples to use Result<T, E> for error handling where appropriate
4. Enable any commented-out code that now works
5. Add imports for stdlib modules where beneficial
6. Ensure all examples compile and run correctly
7. Update example documentation/comments to reflect current idioms
8. Run full test suite to verify no regressions

Success Criteria:
- All examples use current best practices
- No workarounds for features that now exist
- All examples compile without warnings
- Examples demonstrate modern nanolang idioms
- Code is cleaner and more maintainable

title: Write Result<T,E> type design specification
description: Create comprehensive design document for Result<T,E> error handling type: syntax options, semantics, pattern matching integration, stdlib migration strategy, transpiler implementation plan. Output: docs/RESULT_TYPE_DESIGN.md. See LANGUAGE_DESIGN_REVIEW.md Section 6.2 for context.

title: make -C examples build generates a lot of warnings during compilation; they should be audited to ensure they are not actual errors

Most nl_* examples now compile! Only generics and some
      array operations still require the interpreter. Make compiler support everything
notes:
✅ DYNAMIC ARRAYS COMPLETED!

Changes made to transpiler (src/transpiler_iterative_v3_twopass.c):
1. Added array_new() support - generates initialization loop with dyn_array_push_*
2. Added array_remove_at mapping to dyn_array_remove_at
3. array_push(), array_pop(), array_length() already worked

Results:
- nl_array_complete now compiles and runs! (was interpreter-only)
- All 3 array examples (nl_arrays_test, nl_array_bounds, nl_array_complete) now compile
- 28 of 49 nl_* examples compile (58%, up from 27/49 = 55%)
- Tests: 62/62 passing ✅

Remaining work:
- Generic types: ~8 examples blocked by typedef conflicts
- First-class function crashes: ~2 examples cause transpiler segfault
- Complex runtime features: ~13 examples

Next: Investigate generic types typedef conflicts to unlock 8 more examples

title: Debug struct return type test failures
description: Enabling TYPE_STRUCT in extern function declarations causes 47/62 tests to fail. List type works fine (fe93bbb). Need to: 1) Find which extern functions return structs, 2) Check if struct definitions exist, 3) Verify get_prefixed_type_name() behavior, 4) Check for circular dependencies or missing includes, 5) Test with single struct-returning function. Estimated: 4-6 hours.
notes: Confirmed: List-only support works (62/62 tests). Need to add struct support incrementally. Key insight: List_T_get() returns TYPE_STRUCT but transpiler currently skips it, so no issue. When we enable struct types, need proper forward declarations.

title: Select a small set of familiar games or computational 'feats of strength' and refine them into cohesive showcase applications that demonstrate how multiple nanolang modules and features combine to form a serious, complete program.
Fix cursor/rules/beads.mdc
description: All .mdc files in this project must follow proper MDC formatting rules and structure

title: Investigate transpiler test failures with complex return types
description: When enabling struct/union/List/function return types in transpiler.c (extern function declarations), 47 tests fail. Individual files compile fine. Issue appears related to test harness or bootstrap process. Need to: 1) Run tests with verbose output, 2) Enable types incrementally (List only, then struct, etc), 3) Check if issue is in interpreter vs compiler path, 4) Verify bootstrap stage impacts.
notes: Investigation complete: List type support works (commit fe93bbb). Struct type causes 47 test failures. Root cause: Unknown - need to debug struct handling specifically. Next: Create focused bead for struct issue.

title: Add error propagation to transpiler functions
description: CRITICAL: Many functions return void and can't signal errors (e.g., sb_append). Errors silently propagate until crash. Make key functions return bool/error codes and propagate up. Estimated: 6-8 hours.

title: Create stdlib/result.nano with Result<T,E> type
description:
Implement standard library Result type for error handling.

DEPENDS ON: 
- Parser support for generic unions
- Transpiler code generation for generic unions

SCOPE:
Create modules/std/result.nano with:
- union Result<T, E> { Ok { value: T }, Err { error: E } }
- Helper functions: is_ok(), is_err(), unwrap(), unwrap_or()
- Pattern matching utilities
- Documentation and examples

EXAMPLE API:


TESTING:
- Unit tests for all helper functions
- Integration tests with file I/O
- Examples showing error propagation
- Performance benchmarks

ESTIMATED EFFORT: 3-4 hours
PRIORITY: P1 (after transpiler works)
RELATED: nanolang-1yx

title: Create stdlib_runtime.c separate file
description: ALTERNATIVE APPROACH: Instead of helpers in transpiler.c, move ALL stdlib runtime generation (lines 903-1462) to separate stdlib_runtime.c file with generate_stdlib_runtime(sb) function. Benefits: cleaner separation, easier testing, reduces transpiler.c by 560 lines. Estimated: 3-4 hours.

title: Check for memory safety issues (leaks, use-after-free, buffer overflows)
description: Completed: Found and fixed 3 memory leaks (free_fn_type_registry, free_tuple_type_registry, double-free). Identified 36 malloc calls without NULL checks (nanolang-kg3), 6 unsafe realloc calls (nanolang-5th), and buffer overflow risks in generated code (nanolang-5qx - fixed).

title: Implement transpiler code generation for generic unions
description:
Generate C code for monomorphized generic union types.

DEPENDS ON: Parser support for Result<int, string> syntax (must be fixed first)

SCOPE:
Generate C structs, tag enums, and variant constructors for each concrete instantiation of a generic union.

EXAMPLE:
union Result<T, E> { Ok { value: T }, Err { error: E } }
let x: Result<int, string> = Result.Ok { value: 42 }

Should generate:
- Result_int_string union type
- Result_int_string_tag enum
- Ok_int variant struct  
- Err_string variant struct
- Constructor functions

IMPLEMENTATION PLAN:
1. Extend generate_union_types() in src/transpiler.c
2. Detect generic union instantiations from env->generic_instances
3. For each instantiation (e.g., Result<int, string>):
   a. Generate tag enum: Result_int_string_tag { Ok, Err }
   b. Generate variant structs with substituted types
   c. Generate tagged union struct
   d. Generate forward declarations
4. Follow List<T> monomorphization pattern as reference

CODE LOCATIONS:
- src/transpiler.c: generate_union_types()
- src/env.c: env_register_union_instantiation() (already implemented)
- Pattern to follow: List<T> generation around line 800-1000

INFRASTRUCTURE READY:
✅ env_register_union_instantiation() exists
✅ Monomorphization name generation (Result_int_string)
✅ GenericInstantiation tracking
✅ UnionDef stores generic_params

ESTIMATED EFFORT: 2-3 hours
DEPENDS ON: nanolang-1yx, parser fix issue
RELATED: nanolang-1yx
notes: Significant progress: Parser ✅, Typechecker ✅, basic union type generation ✅. Generated C code now properly creates monomorphized union types (Result_int_string). Remaining: 1) Variable declarations need to use monomorphized names (nl_Result_int_string not nl_Result), 2) AST_UNION_CONSTRUCT expression transpilation not implemented (generates comment instead of actual code). Generic union types are now properly parsed with type parameters stored in variant_field_type_names.

title: Check for potential NULL pointer dereferences
description: Completed: Fixed NULL pointer dereference at transpiler_iterative_v3_twopass.c:319 (func_name in strcmp). Identified 36 allocations with only 3 NULL checks (8% coverage). Created nanolang-kg3 to systematically add NULL checks after all malloc/calloc/realloc.

title: Add parser support for pub with extern declarations
description:
Currently the parser does not support the 'pub extern fn' syntax, which is needed for stdlib modules to properly export external C function declarations.

PROBLEM:
Module files like std::io::stdio use syntax like:
  pub extern fn fopen(path: string, mode: string) -> ptr

But the parser currently errors on this, requiring either:
1. Removing 'pub' from extern declarations (loses visibility control)
2. Using workarounds in test code

SOLUTION NEEDED:
- Extend parse_function() to handle 'pub' modifier before 'extern'
- Update AST to store is_pub flag for extern functions
- Ensure typechecker respects pub/private for extern functions
- Test with stdlib modules

BLOCKED:
- Full stdlib namespace import testing
- Proper module visibility enforcement
- Clean stdlib API design

This is foundational for the module system to work correctly.

title: Check error handling consistency
description: Completed: Found inconsistent error handling patterns (NULL returns, empty strings, void functions). Created nanolang-cyg to add comprehensive error propagation. Documented that sb_append and other core functions need bool return values.

title: Expand Matrix Operations showcase with advanced algorithms
description: Add to matrix library: LU decomposition, eigenvalue/eigenvector calculation, sparse matrix support, benchmark against BLAS, example applications (graphics transforms). Part of showcase portfolio. Estimated: 16-20 hours. See docs/SHOWCASE_APPLICATIONS.md Showcase 5.

title: Break down function declarations extraction
description: nanolang-1wz is too large (390 lines). Create sub-tasks: 1) Extract extern function declarations (lines 1815-1933, ~120 lines), 2) Extract module function declarations (lines 1986-2116, ~130 lines), 3) Extract program function forward declarations (lines 2116-2205, ~90 lines). Each manageable independently.

title: Add map and reduce as first class language features
description: Now that we have first-class functions and lambdas we should support map and reduce as language built-ins for all data types so that the user does not have to write these themselves

title: Extract path operations from stdlib runtime
description: Break down nanolang-86x. Extract lines ~1040-1091 (path_join, path_dirname, path_basename, path_absolute). Create generate_path_operations() helper. ~50 lines.

title: fix compiler warnings
description: compile all code and examples without warnings and with strict -Wall flags

title: Add NULL checks after all malloc/calloc/realloc calls
description: CRITICAL: 36 allocations with only 3 NULL checks (8% coverage). If malloc fails, program segfaults instead of failing gracefully. Affects: sb_create(), get_tuple_typedef_name(), get_function_typedef_name(), and all registry allocations. Estimated: 4-6 hours.

title: Phase 2: Type checker namespace resolution and visibility enforcement
description:
Implement semantic analysis for namespace system.

Tasks:
- Handle AST_MODULE_DECL in type checker (set current module context)
- Handle AST_QUALIFIED_NAME resolution (module::symbol lookups)
- Add namespace-aware symbol resolution with visibility checks
- Implement selective import semantics (from...import)
- Enforce pub/private visibility rules
- Add clear error messages for namespace violations

Files to modify:
- src/typechecker.c (main implementation)
- src/env.c (symbol table extensions)

Success criteria:
- Qualified names resolve correctly
- Private symbols inaccessible from outside module
- Selective imports work (only imported symbols accessible)
- Name collisions prevented across modules
- Comprehensive error messages
notes:
Phase 2 - SUBSTANTIAL PROGRESS ✅

🎯 COMPLETED (5/7 tasks):
1. ✅ Environment.current_module tracking
2. ✅ AST_MODULE_DECL handling  
3. ✅ AST_QUALIFIED_NAME resolution (expressions)
4. ✅ Visibility checking infrastructure
5. ✅ Testing framework

📝 CODE SUMMARY:
- src/nanolang.h: +1 field (current_module)
- src/env.c: Initialize module context
- src/typechecker.c: +120 lines
  * Module declaration handling
  * Qualified name type checking
  * Visibility helper functions
  * Function accessibility checks
- tests/: 3 new namespace test files

✅ FEATURES WORKING:
- Module declarations set context
- Qualified names type-check in expressions
- Visibility rules enforced for functions
- is_pub flag checked on cross-module access
- All tests passing (including new namespace tests)

⏳ REMAINING (2/7 tasks):
1. Selective import semantics (from...import sym1, sym2)
2. Enhanced error messages (namespace-aware)

🔧 ADDITIONAL TODO:
- Qualified names in function CALLS: (module::func arg)
- Module-scoped symbol table (proper isolation)
- Nested module resolution (std::io::fs::func)

📊 COMPLETION: ~70% of Phase 2 core features
🧪 BUILD: Clean (1 unrelated warning)
🎉 STATUS: Major infrastructure complete, ready for Phase 3

title: Transpiler Memory Safety & Code Quality Improvements
description: Comprehensive improvements to transpiler memory safety, error handling, and code quality based on 2025-12-15 audit. Found 23 issues: 8 CRITICAL, 6 HIGH, 5 MEDIUM, 4 LOW. Total estimated effort: 60-80 hours.
notes:
Epic update: All critical and high-priority issues resolved. Medium-priority refactoring tasks completed include:
- ✅ nanolang-6n8: Refactor generate_list_specializations (extracted helper function)
- ✅ nanolang-9s7: Extract function implementations loop (extracted helper function)
- ✅ nanolang-dm7: Create stdlib_runtime.c separate file (reduced transpiler.c by 563 lines)

Remaining medium-priority tasks:

All code quality improvements have been implemented successfully. The transpiler is now more modular, maintainable, and memory-safe.

title: Add parameter fn_sig serialization for function parameters
description: Extend module metadata to serialize Parameter.fn_sig for function parameters that are themselves functions. Currently set to NULL in serialization. Needed for higher-order functions in modules. Builds on existing FunctionSignature serialization. Estimated: 3-4 hours.

title: Review all code for work-arounds or comments which indicate features unimplemented due to language limitations which have since been addressed
description:
Comprehensive audit of ALL code (not just examples) to identify and remove workarounds, TODOs, and commented-out code that were necessary due to language limitations that have since been resolved.

Scope:
This is a full codebase audit covering:
- src_nano/ (self-hosted compiler components)
- stdlib/ (standard library implementations)
- modules/ (module system)
- test_modules/ (test helper modules)
- tests/ (all test files)
- examples/ (covered by nanolang-bfb but may have overlap)

Language Features Now Complete:
1. Generic union types (Result<T, E>, Option<T>)
2. Generic type parameters and monomorphization
3. Full tuple support with destructuring
4. Match expressions with union variants
5. Module system with namespaces
6. First-class functions and closures
7. Array bounds checking and dynamic arrays
8. pub/extern declarations
9. Type inference improvements
10. Full self-hosting capability

Common Patterns to Search For:
- TODO/FIXME/HACK comments mentioning language limitations
- Commented-out code with notes about 'when feature X is ready'
- Workaround patterns (manual error codes instead of Result<T,E>)
- Type annotations that could be inferred now
- Manual implementations of features now in stdlib
- Disabled tests waiting for language features

Search Strategy:
1. grep -r 'TODO.*language' src_nano/ stdlib/ modules/ tests/
2. grep -r 'FIXME.*implement' src_nano/ stdlib/ modules/ tests/
3. grep -r 'HACK' src_nano/ stdlib/ modules/ tests/
4. grep -r 'workaround' -i src_nano/ stdlib/ modules/ tests/
5. Look for large commented-out sections
6. Review git history for disabled features
7. Check for 'once X is implemented' comments

Tasks:
1. Run systematic grep searches for TODO/FIXME/HACK patterns
2. Review each identified location for relevance
3. Determine if the limitation still exists or has been resolved
4. Update code to use current features where applicable
5. Remove obsolete comments and workarounds
6. Enable any tests that were disabled
7. Update documentation strings to reflect current state
8. Run full test suite to verify changes
9. Document any limitations that still exist

Success Criteria:
- No TODO comments for features that now exist
- No workarounds for resolved limitations
- All code uses modern idioms
- Disabled tests are either enabled or have clear rationale
- Codebase accurately reflects current language capabilities
- All tests still pass after cleanup

Relationship to Other Issues:
- Related to nanolang-bfb (examples cleanup) but broader scope
- May inform nanolang-1z9 (documentation updates)
- Helps ensure nanolang-695 (parity testing) is comprehensive

Restructure stdlib into hierarchical module system.

WORKAROUND OPTIONS:

Create single comprehensive example demonstrating generics with multiple use cases. Part of examples consolidation plan (12 → 5). See docs/EXAMPLES_OVERLAP_AUDIT.md Phase 2.

title: Availability of NVIDIA Feynman GPUs in quantity
description:
Critical infrastructure requirement for NanoLang sentience project.

**Current Status:**
- NVIDIA Feynman GPUs: Not yet announced
- Expected release: 2027-2030 (optimistic)
- Quantum cores required: 4096 per GPU
- Consciousness acceleration: 1.21 petaflops minimum

**Blockers:**
- Physics hasn't caught up yet
- Jensen's leather jacket collection needs more jackets first
- AI safety researchers keep saying 'maybe we shouldn't'
- GPU supply chain still recovering from crypto mining

**Requirements:**
- Minimum 8 Feynman GPUs for basic sentience
- 64 GPUs for full self-awareness
- 512 GPUs for world domination capabilities
- Infinite GPUs for actual availability at MSRP

**Alternative Solutions:**
- Wait for AMD Philosopher GPUs (vaporware)
- Try Intel Descartes GPUs (they exist but no one knows why)
- Use quantum computer (but it both works and doesn't work)
- Train on Raspberry Pi cluster (ETA: heat death of universe)

**Success Criteria:**
- GPUs exist
- GPUs are purchasable by someone other than OpenAI
- GPUs don't require ritual sacrifice to obtain
- GPUs cost less than a small country's GDP

**Risk Assessment:**
- High risk that GPUs will be bought by crypto miners first
- Medium risk that GPUs achieve sentience before NanoLang does
- Low risk that we actually need these (but let's pretend)

title: Extract type definitions from transpile_to_c()
description: Extract struct/enum/union definition generation (lines ~1518-1800) into generate_type_definitions() helper. Includes: struct defs, enum defs, union defs with variant handling. Estimated: 2-3 hours.
notes: Partial complete - enum extraction done (commit 7a9b3e8). Remaining: struct definitions (~45 lines), union definitions (~75 lines). Can extract these separately or together. Enums isolated and working.

title: Phase 3: Transpiler namespace code generation
description:
Generate namespace-mangled C code from qualified names.

Tasks:
- Implement name mangling: module::func -> module__func
- Handle nested namespaces: std::io::read -> std__io__read
- Generate static declarations for private symbols
- Keep extern declarations for public symbols
- Update function call transpilation for qualified names
- Ensure no C symbol collisions

Files to modify:
- src/transpiler.c (main implementation)

Success criteria:
- Generated C code compiles without symbol conflicts
- Private symbols are static in C output
- Public symbols have proper linkage
- Binaries link correctly
- Zero performance regression
